pullRequest.body:
Define a Galois connection from an arbitrary relation and prove this induces inverse bijections between two sets of fixed points.    

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2949c038ee](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14908/commits/2949c038ee2a7006f47a2b87a30560e7972cb4e4)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Order.Rel.GaloisConnection`|336|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ equivFixedPoints`
`+ gc_leftDual_rightDual`
`+ leftDual`
`+ leftDual_mem_rightFixedPoint`
`+ leftDual_rightDual_le_of_le`
`+ leftFixedPoints`
`+ rightDual`
`+ rightDual_leftDual_le_of_le`
`+ rightDual_mem_leftFixedPoint`
`+ rightFixedPoints`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10078997924/job/27865259686)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10078997924/job/27865260867)

Thanks!

maintainer merge
Thanks for making those changes! This is getting quite close to being ready to merge!

Thanks!

maintainer merge
Could you please give this (and `u` below) a more descriptive name?

@adamtopaz, I first used `lAdjMap` (resp.`rAdjMap`) for the left (resp. right) map of the adjunction, then realised it would be more coherent wrt to the file `GaloisConnection.lean` (which doesn't rely on the category theory library) to use `l` and `u`.
Do you think `lAdjMap` (resp. `uAdjMap`? or still `rAdjMap`?) would be more suitable?

I think `l` should be named something like `rightDual` and `u` something like `leftDual`. Also, I think it's better to introduce these definitions without the order duals, develop an API for the definitions directly, then package that API in the Galois connection at the very end. So, for example, I envision that `rightDual` would be defined as 
```lean
def rightDual (J : Set α) : Set β := {b : β | ∀ a ∈ J, R a b}
```
and analogously for `leftDual`. 

Concerning the names, @YaelDillies would probably have a better sense of how to name these.

> I think `l` should be named something like `rightDual` and `u` something like `leftDual`. 

I assume you mean the other way around, i.e. `l` should be named `leftDual`.
Not sure I understand what API you envision, but I renamed `l` (resp. `u`) into `leftDual` (resp. `rightDual`).

> I think it's better to introduce these definitions without the order duals, develop an API for the definitions directly, then package that API in the Galois connection at the very end.

I second this.
@adamtopaz, Would be happy to implement this, but I would need a precise specification of what you want here.
See https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14908#discussion_r1685417366
`to_galoisConnection` doesn't follow our naming conventions for mathlib.

It's a term of the proposition `GaloisConnection (l R) (u R)`, so should be `snake_case`, right? And `GaloisConnection`, which is `UpperCamelCase` and part of it, should be referenced in `lowerCamelCase`. Is it any different than #[OrderIso.to_galoisConnection](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/GaloisConnection.html#OrderIso.to_galoisConnection)?
`OrderIso.to_galoisConnection` is actually misnamed as well. It should be `OrderIso.galoisConnection` or `OrderIso.gc`
Ok, so it should simply be `Rel.galoisConnection` or without the prefix `galoisConnection`? Just for my personal enlightenment, which naming convention(s) `to_galoisConnection` doesn't follow?
`to` is only used for forgetful inheritance of structures
I'm not sure why you called this `instEquiv...` as this is not an instance.
Relic of a former error. Would `equivFixedPoints` be suitable?
Yes, I think that's a reasonable name. Thanks!
We avoid nonterminal `simp`s in tactic blocks.
It's not clear to me why you would want to tag this with `simp`. Similarly for the lemma below.

```suggestion
def leftDual (J : Set α) : (Set β)ᵒᵈ := toDual {b : β | ∀ ⦃a⦄, a ∈ J → R a b}
```
so that you don't need to provide both `a` and `ha : a ∈ J` when trying to deduce `R a b` from `b ∈ leftDual J`.
Same here

```suggestion
    · constructor <;> intro h <;> apply h
```

This is not in line with the style guide. Please put at most one tactic per line unless one of the following applies:
* It's a one-line proof
* The tactics are chained with `<;>`
Line 62 and line 63 shouldn't be considered one-line proofs, although they close a goal?
No, they are part of a proof that's longer than one line. They are one-line *sub*proofs.

```suggestion
theorem leftDual_mem_rFixedPoint (J : Set α) : leftDual R J ∈ rFixedPoints R := by
```

```suggestion
theorem rightDual_mem_lFixedPoint (I : (Set β)ᵒᵈ) : rightDual R I ∈ lFixedPoints R := by
```

```suggestion
def equivFixedPoints : lFixedPoints R ≃ rFixedPoints R where
  toFun := fun ⟨J, _⟩ => ⟨leftDual R J, is_rFixedPoint R J⟩
  invFun := fun ⟨I, _⟩ => ⟨rightDual R I, is_lFixedPoint R I⟩
  left_inv J := by cases' J with J hJ; simp; rw [hJ]
  right_inv I := by cases' I with I hI; simp; rw [hI]
```
Always a space between `rw` and `[`

```suggestion
theorem le_imp_u_l_le {J J' : Set α} (h : J' ∈ lFixedPoints R) (h₁ : J ≤ J') :
    rightDual R (leftDual R J) ≤ J' := by
  rw [← h]
  apply (galoisConnection R).monotone_u
  apply (galoisConnection R).monotone_l
  exact h₁
```
Same here

```suggestion
      · intro h a ha b hb
```

```suggestion
      · intro h b hb a ha
```

```suggestion
        exact h (by simpa) hb
```
or something like that?
Same here

`where` notation lets introduce variables left to the `:=`
```suggestion
  left_inv J := by cases' J with J hJ; simp; rw [hJ]
  right_inv I := by cases' I with I hI; simp; rw [hI]
```

... and
```suggestion
theorem galoisConnection : GaloisConnection (toDual ∘ leftDual R) (rightDual R ∘ ofDual) := by
```

@YaelDillies @adamtopaz 
I don't see what you really gain with these changes, it seems that things have just been moved around. However, please note that the definition of `rFixedPoints` will be far more cumbersome, in particular you will break the symmetry in the expressions of `lFixedPoints` and `rFixedPoints`. 
By this, I mean that `rFixedPoints` will become 
```
def rFixedPoints := {I : (Set β)ᵒᵈ | toDual (R.leftDual (R.rightDual (ofDual I))) = I}
```
instead of `def rFixedPoints := {I : (Set β)ᵒᵈ | R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) = I}`. 
Moreover, you won't be able to remove the mention of the dual order `(Set β)ᵒᵈ` in `rFixedPoints`. 
Is it really what you want?

Why can't it simply be
```
def rFixedPoints := {I : Set β | R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) = I}
```
?
In this case, how will you prove `leftDual_mem_rFixedPoint`, i.e. that an image is a fixed-point?
Same proof. Why would it change? You're just adding a bunch of "identity" isomorphisms here and there, and they cancel out

The adjoint maps now are (`toDual \circ leftDual`, `rightDual \circ ofDual`), not (`leftDual`, `rightDual`) anymore. You can still express the property of `J` being a left fixed point with `R.rightDual (R.leftDual J) = J`, since `(rightDual \circ ofDual) \circ (toDual \circ leftDual) = rightDual \circ leftDual`, i.e. the additional isos cancel out, but for a right fixed point they don't cancel out, the property of being a right fixed point have to use `(toDual \circ leftDual) \circ (rightDual \circ ofDual)` \neq `\leftDual \circ rightDual` (these last two maps are not even of the same type, i.e. automorphism of `(Set β)ᵒᵈ` vs of `Set β`).
Am I missing something?

Sorry, not at a computer right now but morally if your statements are not about orders, then they shouldn't need anything related to `OrderDual`. `rFixedPoints_mem_rDual` isn't about order so you shouldn't need `OrderDual`, even though the intermediate lemma `galoisConnection` needs it.

Thank you for your reply and sorry to bother on a Sunday, Yael :)
>if your statements are not about orders

I believe there are, no? $I$ being a fixed point under $F$ means $I \leq F (I)$ and $F(I)\leq I$.
Moreover, if these statements weren't about orders, you would prevent yourself from using the API for Galois connections ... so, there would be no point in proving that the induced bijections between fixed points come from a Galois connection. 
Since the change was suggested by Adam, maybe he can help?

I'm not saying it *can't* be interpreted as an order theoretic statement, but rather that it *can* be interpreted without order theory. If all else fails, I'll be back at a computer first thing tomorrow morning ;)
Done. Does our suggestion make more sense now?
Thank you, Yael. I left a comment below https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14908#discussion_r1686241361
Should this mention of the dual order `(Set β)ᵒᵈ` also been removed?
Yep, well spotted!
Deleted. I'm happy with the changes. Thanks a lot Yael for your time and effort!
This filename reads `Relto` + `Galois` + `Connection`. Can you fix the case?
Sure. Should it be `RelToGaloisConnection`? What are the conventions for file names?
To rename the file not only locally on my computer, but also in my GitHub branch, what should I do? Run `lake exe mk_all`?

This has nothing to do with `lake exe mk_all` (although you should also run that). To git, renaming a file is the same as removing all the content of a file and adding a bunch of content to another file. These are things that git tracks, so you should create a commit as usual.
Done.

```suggestion
  intros J I
  change ∀ b ∈ ofDual I, ∀ a ∈ J, R a b)
  constructor
  · intro h a ha b hb
    exact h (by simpa) hb a ha
  · intro h b hb a ha
    exact h (by simpa) hb
```
or even just
```suggestion
  fun J I ↦ ⟨fun h a ha b hb ↦ h (by simpa) hb a ha,
    fun h b hb a hah b hb a ha ↦ h (by simpa) hb⟩
```
The naming convention is `conclusion_of_premise`, not `premise_imp_conclusion`

```suggestion
/-- `rightDual` maps any set `I` of elements of type `β` to the set `{a : α | ∀ b ∈ I, R a b}`
```

It's not clear to me what you mean by "generation process". I think a more descriptive title would be something like the following:
```suggestion
/-! ### Induced equivalences between fixed points. -/
```
Can you please rename this `leftFixedPoints` (and similarly for the right fixed points)?

```suggestion
  rw [← h]
```
Since the names of `u` and `l` have been changed, the names of this and the following lemma should be changed accordingly as well.

This can be turned into a proof term as follows:

```suggestion
theorem leftDual_mem_rightFixedPoint (J : Set α) : R.leftDual J ∈ R.rightFixedPoints :=
  le_antisymm (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.le_u_l J))
    (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.l_u_le (R.leftDual J))
```

I have tested the code so you can safely commit this suggestion if you like.
Are proof terms or tactics preferred in mathlib4, wrt legibility, maintenance etc?
Really depends on the length. Here I think a tactic proof is justified

As far as I know, there is no general convention in mathlib4 regarding the preference between proof terms and tactics. 

In my personal experience as an author (~ 7 months) and as a reviewer (~ 1 month), for relatively simple and short proofs such as these, fewer lines of code (and possibly faster execution) are typically considered better. 

Given a 5-10 lines simple proof (e.g. an `intro` and a sequence of `apply`s), I think we can fairly say that a 1-2 lines proof term is better.

I don’t believe there is any significant loss in readability and maintainability in this case. 

Please @YaelDillies, correct me if I'm wrong.
Ops, sorry @YaelDillies. For some reason your previous comment didn't show up on the mobile app...
I think it's just not a big deal either way

The only comment I have about these tactic blocks is that the `unfold` step is (most likely) unnecessary, and that's one tactic that we tend to avoid in mathlib proofs. @AnthonyBordg, could you try to get rid of these `unfold`s in your proofs?
Done. Howewer, I have an error after renaming the file `Order.Rel.GaloisConnection` as suggested by Yael.
Seems like you forgot to run `lake exe mk_all`
I did run `lake exe mk_all`.

This can be turned into a proof term as follows:

```suggestion
theorem rightDual_mem_lFixedPoint (I : Set β) : R.rightDual I ∈ R.lFixedPoints :=
  le_antisymm (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.l_u_le I)) (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.le_u_l (R.rightDual I))
```

I have tested the code so you can safely commit this suggestion if you like.

This can be turned into a proof term as follows:

```suggestion
theorem ge_l_u_of_ge {I I' : Set β} (h : I' ∈ R.rFixedPoints) :
    I' ≥ I → I' ≥ R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) :=
  fun h₁ ↦ h ▸ R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u h₁)
```

I have tested the code so you can safely commit this suggestion if you like.

This can be turned into a proof term as follows:

```suggestion
theorem u_l_le_of_le {J J' : Set α} (h : J' ∈ R.lFixedPoints) :
    J ≤ J' → R.rightDual (R.leftDual J) ≤ J' :=
  fun h₁ ↦ h ▸ R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l h₁)
```

I have tested the code so you can safely commit this suggestion if you like.

Updated:

```suggestion
theorem leftDual_mem_rightFixedPoint (J : Set α) : R.leftDual J ∈ R.rightFixedPoints :=
  le_antisymm (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.le_u_l J))
    (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.l_u_le (R.leftDual J))
```

Updated: 

```suggestion
theorem rightDual_mem_leftFixedPoint (I : Set β) : R.rightDual I ∈ R.leftFixedPoints :=
  le_antisymm (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.l_u_le I))
    (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.le_u_l (R.rightDual I))
```

Updated: 

```suggestion
theorem rightDual_leftDual_le_of_le {J J' : Set α} (h : J' ∈ R.leftFixedPoints) :
    J ≤ J' → R.rightDual (R.leftDual J) ≤ J' :=
  fun h₁ ↦ h ▸ R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l h₁)
```

Updated:

```suggestion
theorem ge_leftDual_rightDual_of_ge {I I' : Set β} (h : I' ∈ R.rightFixedPoints) :
    I' ≥ I → I' ≥ R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) :=
  fun h₁ ↦ h ▸ R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_l (R.gc_leftDual_rightDual.monotone_u h₁)
```
This name should be fully qualified (adn updated!)
And this one too

```suggestion
  of fixed points.
```

```suggestion
⋆ Engendrement de topologies, démontrabilité et opérations sur les sous-topos, Olivia Caramello and
  Laurent Lafforgue (in preparation)
```
or
```suggestion
Engendrement de topologies, démontrabilité et opérations sur les sous-topos, Olivia Caramello and
Laurent Lafforgue (in preparation)
```
After some thought, `Order.Rel.GaloisConnection` seems to be a better name for this file

Some help with this error `uncaught exception: no such file or directory (error code: 2)
  file: Mathlib/Order/«Order/Rel/GaloisConnection».lean`?
The intention was to rename it to `GaloisConnection.lean` in the `Mathlib/Order/Rel/` directory (so that it could be imported with `import Mathlib.Order.Rel.GaloisConnection`).
I do not see any `Mathlib/Order/Rel` directory, am I supposed to create one?
Yes please!

Please never `≥` but always `≤`. We don't want people having to guess two names and two statements
```suggestion
theorem leftDual_rightDual_le_of_le {I I' : Set β} (h : I' ∈ R.rightFixedPoints) :
    I ≤ I' → R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) ≤ I' := by
```
also you might as well pull out the assumption to before the colon
```suggestion
theorem leftDual_rightDual_le_of_le {I I' : Set β} (h : I' ∈ R.rightFixedPoints) (h₁ : I ≤ I') :
    R.leftDual (R.rightDual I) ≤ I' := by
```

> Please never `≥` but always `≤`. We don't want people having to guess two names and two statements

Make sense! Done.

```suggestion
theorem rightDual_leftDual_le_of_le {J J' : Set α} (h : J' ∈ R.leftFixedPoints) (h₁ : J ≤ J') :
```
This section is kind of useless. Miht as well remove it

Unless necessary, we usually just do 
```suggestion
variable {α β : Type*} (R : Rel α β)
```

Don't need these anymore
```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the Galois connection induced by an arbitrary relation
